;

; What are people who are always unhappy thinking about?

;
;
;
;
; Simple psychological answer
;
;

;

;;
;

;Everyone has experienced it unhappy. And those who are unhappy for a long time may be caused by their negative thinking.

;

;;How we control this negative thinking affects whether we are confident or fearful, full of hope or despair, whether we have autonomy or feel controlled, and even whether we can obtain success. ;

;

;Many studies have confirmed that persistent negative thinking will reduce health and happiness. Here are 8 common negative thoughts to alert you to:

;

;  

;

;; 1. Self-defeat;

;

;Sometimes, we say bad things to ourselves, which will lower our self-confidence and underestimate ourselves. potential, making us perform worse. In this case, it usually starts like this:

;

;“I can't do it...”

;

;“I'm not good enough…”

;

;“I'm not sure…”

;

;“I don't have it yet…”

;

;“I'm going to fail…”

;< p>;Just imagine, if you have a friend like this who tells you "you are not good enough", "you are not good at this", "you will not succeed" every day, you will still feel Is this person a true friend who has good intentions for you?

;

;If not, how can you bear to say these words to yourself every day? ! ;Doing this kind of self-attack on yourself every day is like having an insincere friend and letting that friend slander you all day long. ;Over time, I have become my most hated enemy.

;

;  

;

;; 2. Negative thinking;

;

;A common form of negative thinking is this: The current situation is evaluated and assumed to be a negative state.

;

;For many people, the classic view of "half a bottle of water" will form a habitual and automatic attitude pattern over time. People with such habitual thinking will automatically process things like crowded buses and rainy days into a negative feeling.

;

;;We all know that traffic and weather are not inherently positive or negative attributes. And when you selectively relate these to the situations you experience, these things can take on a positive or negative color. ;

;

;  

;

;; 3. Always feel that you are inferior to others;

;

;This is the simplest way And the most common way to make yourself feel bad: making yourself feel inferior to others.

;

;In particular, we often compare ourselves with those who have more, those who are more attractive, those who can make more money, and even those who have more likes in their circle of friends.

;

;When you feel that you particularly want to have what others have, or you feel jealous or inferior to others, it means that you may be experiencing a negative social comparison.

;

;;  ;

;

;; 4. Always thinking about bad things in the past: negative rumination;

;

;It is true that we need to learn from the past and draw lessons from history, but we cannot be trapped by the past. This is because sometimes, past life difficulties and personal setbacks can blind us to our true potential and new opportunities.

;

;We cannot change what has happened. But those things that haven’t happened yet, we can definitely change or influence. The first step to change and influence is to break through the barriers of the "past" and clearly declare to yourself: ;The person who can control the present is me now, not the me in the past. ;

;

; 

;

;; 5. Always feel that the opponent is difficult ;

;

;We will definitely encounter some difficulties. A troublesome person. When facing these difficult people, people will subconsciously regard the other party as the "controlling party", while they themselves will take the role of the "controlled party".

;

;This kind of knowledge, even if it is objective, will greatly weaken our autonomy.

;

;If you want to change this unconfident state of facing a difficult opponent, the most important thing is to reverse your own perception, whether you are facing a narcissist, a control monster, or For veterans who are passive aggressive, I believe you can search for information and find corresponding techniques on the Internet or in books, allowing you to occupy the commanding heights of interaction (or, at least, a relatively equal position).

;

; 

;

;; 6. Always blaming;

;

;What is blaming? Here, we can understand it as “ Things are responsible for our misfortunes."

;

;Many people blame their unhappiness or failure on ineffective parents, negative intimate relationships, poor socio-economic conditions, health conditions, or life. hardships.

;

;Although it is an indisputable fact that life is difficult, and it is also undeniable that such hardship often brings pain. But often citing other people or external objects as the cause of one's own unhappiness also projects a "victim" mentality.

;

;However, over time, this habitual blame will make the pain, resentment, and powerlessness become lasting, and the "victim" role will also suffer what Thoreau called "Still despair".

;

;;Your feelings may be objectively correct, but they will not help you become happier, healthier, or more successful. All you will get is complaints and more despair. ;

;

; 

;

;; 7. Not forgiving yourself;

;

;We all make mistakes. When you look back on the past, there will be some decisions or actions that you regret, or you may have unfortunately made some wrong judgments, or you may have caused harm to yourself or others.

;

;Whenever you think of these past events, you may be accompanied by a feeling of blaming yourself, especially for those unintentional mistakes, harm that has been caused, or opportunities that were missed. You may even feel like you're a bad person and wallow in guilt.

;

;At this time, it is very important to have more empathy for yourself. Believe that you have learned a lesson and are now better able to avoid those mistakes and do more positive things for yourself and others.

;

; 

;

;; 8. Fear of failure or making mistakes;

;

;The fear of failure and making mistakes is related to perfectionism to a certain extent. Relationships (perfectionism here refers to perfectionism in a certain area of ​​life), sometimes you may think that you are not good enough in some aspects and put tremendous pressure on yourself to do better.

;

;;Although holding yourself to high standards can serve as a tool to maintain high motivation, expecting perfection from yourself can take away much of the joy in life and may limit your potential for success. . ;Many studies have confirmed the link between perfectionism and unhappiness.
